column1: 0;PAYX;Paychex Inc;2018-09-25T18:50:40Z;Square hits record high after rolling out payroll managing app;;Shares in Square hit a record high after the payments group said it was introducing a mobile app that would allow businesses to manage their payroll.Square
column2: which is founded and headed by Jack Dorsey of Twitter
column3: is rolling out a dedicated mobile app for its appropriately named Payroll suite of services that will allow vendors to manage employee wages
column4: and other things such as tax withholdings and filings
column5: while on the go.Investors welcomed the news and pushed Square shares up 10.2 per cent to $94.77 in afternoon trade. That put the stock on track for a record closing high and a market capitalisation of about $39bn.It was seen as a less favourable development for rival payments services providers
column6: with PayChex down 1.3 per cent and Automatic Data Processing down 0.2 per cent.

column1: 1;PAYX;Paychex Inc;2017-11-07T18:30:38Z;ADP/Ackman: from gadfly to sad guy;Pershing Square founder has lost his groove;"As an intensely competitive tennis player
column2: Bill Ackman knows the United States Tennis Association’s handicap system. If there were such a ranking for activist investors
column3: he would have just dropped down it by a rung or two. His fund
column5: lost decisively on Tuesday in its efforts to catapult three representatives on the board of ADP
column6: a payroll processor worth $50bn.Pershing Square has been bloodied by billions of losses at Valeant Pharmaceuticals and struggled to make a return at the burrito chain Chipotle. ADP made a tricky target as its shares are up 142 per cent in the last five years. Public sniping with its chief executive did not endear the corporate gadfly to shareholders. Activists’ most potent tool is their credibility. Mr Ackman has lost much of his.His case at ADP was delicately crafted. Despite big shareholder gains during the tenure of CEO Carlos Rodriguez the company’s profit margins are weak compared with rival Paychex. The company is set to be surpassed by hotshot Silicon Valley outsourcers like Workday.Powerful proxy adviser
column7: ISS said Mr Ackman had made the case that “some additional shareholder oversight at the board would be beneficial”. But it advocated its clients should put him on the board in a roundabout way; by withholding votes for certain directors on the company’s ballot rather than explicitly voting for Mr Ackman’s separate slate. US proxy voting is byzantine but Mr Ackman makes a reasonable case when he advocates for single “universal ballot” where shareholders can mix and match their votes across slates.Given the structural barriers Pershing Square was facing
column8: irritating a respected CEO was dangerous even if his operational arguments were compelling. Mr Rodriguez at one point called Mr Ackman a “spoiled brat” and then referred to Mr Ackman’s defeat on Tuesday as an “ass-whooping”. Pershing Square likes to point out that its fund is up 500 per cent since its 2004 inception. But it was up nearly 800 per cent three years ago; big wins at the likes of Canadian Pacific Railway are now dusty trophies.Because of past activists wins and the awakening of big passive funds
column9: companies have upgraded their governance. Fewer easy targets exist. Mr Ackman needs to target one playing off his own diminished handicap to get his groove back."

column1: 2;PAYX;Paychex Inc;2020-04-25T06:00:28+0000;All-male boards in the US face investor backlash;LGIM will target directors at companies without any women on their boards;"Britain’s largest asset manager has pledged to start voting against directors at US companies that have failed to appoint a woman to their board
column2: as investors become increasingly frustrated by the continued prevalence of male-dominated boardrooms.Legal & General Investment Management
column3: the London-based fund company that oversees $1tn of assets
column4: has toughened its voting stance after deciding that simply urging US companies to take action on board diversity has not delivered results.LGIM began pushing for better board diversity in the US seven years ago. It will vote against nomination committee chairmen at any company in the S&P 500 index that still has an all-male board from 2017 onwards.Clare Payn
column5: head of corporate governance for North America at the UK fund house
column6: said: “We feel there really should not be any all-male boards at this stage
column7: as investors have been talking about this for so many years.”According to S&P Dow Jones
column9: four S&P 500 companies still have an all-male board: Coty
column10: the beauty products manufacturer; Dentsply Sirona
column12: a provider of human resources services; and TransDigm Group
column13: the manufacturer of parts for commercial and military aircraft.Another 177 companies in the S&P 1500 index
column14: and 18 companies in the MSCI USA index of America’s 622 biggest businesses
column15: have no female directors. Join us on April 19 for a conversation about women in the corporate worldLGIM’s stance goes further than most of its competitors. Several of the world’s largest fund companies
column19: are pressing for greater gender diversity on boards
column20: but have not committed to voting against directors at companies with all-male boardrooms.Helena Morrissey
column21: a leading campaigner for gender equality in the workplace
column22: urged other investors to harden their approach to the remaining companies lacking female directors.Ms Morrissey
column23: who will become head of personal investing at LGIM next month after leaving Newton
column26: said she felt “exasperated” by the lack of progress on board diversity in the US.She said: “If a company doesn’t change [its board structure]
column27: then [investors] ultimately should vote against at least the chair of the nomination committee. It is bizarre that you would not [apply a tougher voting policy]. It is a failure.”A spokesperson for PayChex said a female director had recently resigned
column28: and that a “search is actively under way for her successor”
column29: while Coty said it planned to add a woman to its board before July. A spokesperson for Dentsply Sirona said: “We see [diversity] as a priority in future board member selection.” TransDigm did not respond to requests for comment.Investors are concerned about the lack of female directors in many of the world’s largest economies. Numerous academic studies have suggested companies with diverse boardrooms perform better
column31: and avoid groupthink.Women account for 20 per cent of directorships in the US
column32: compared with 25 per cent in the UK and Australia
column33: and more than 35 per cent in France and Norway
column35: the data provider.Last week Hermes EOS
column36: an influential adviser to large investors
column37: urged Rio Tinto shareholders to vote against the re-election of the Anglo-Australian mining company’s chairman at its annual general meeting because of slow progress in improving the diversity of its board.LGIM decided to vote against all-male boards at Britain’s largest companies in 2015
column38: and extended that policy to include FTSE 250 companies last year. Aviva Investors
column40: also decided to vote against all-male boardrooms in the UK in 2014.Since these voting positions were adopted
column48: have appointed female board members.Abigail Herron
column49: head of responsible investment at Aviva Investors
column50: said the fund house plans to extend its UK voting policy to companies with all-male boards in North America
column51: Europe and Japan.She said: “Having a voting policy against all-male boards is a very useful tool. It is such a powerful way to drive change.”Ms Payn added: “Of course it would be helpful if other [investors] took a tougher stance on all-male boards. I will not sit here and tell them how they should vote
column52: but if we collectively came together
column53: that would push companies even further.”ConvaTec
column54: the UK provider of healthcare products that floated last October
column55: is the only company in the FTSE 100 without a female board member.The number of companies in the FTSE 250 without a woman on their board has more than halved since 2015
column56: to nine. The remaining companies with all-male boardrooms include Euromoney Institutional Investor
